title: Rich Lister's $400m world of pain at Pact
text:
"I'm not going to try and get volume at any cost,'' he said.

Mr Dayal, who worked for steel group BlueScope for nine years until 2018, took the helm at Pact in early April, with Mr Geminder reverting back to chairman.

Mr Dayal is part-way through a strategic review and said that Pact had expanded too quickly and tried to do too much. It has about 80 packaging plants and Mr Dayal said that was probably too many. It had also been too slow to respond to changing market conditions.

"This needs to be corrected,'' Mr Dayal said.

He said a large part of the strategic review would be completed by the end of the December half.

"I believe we can reinvent Pact,'' he said. Momentum should begin to build within 12 to 18 months. "It's about really getting the core right.''

Mr Geminder took over the day-to-day running of the business in an expanded executive chairman role in September 2018 following the abrupt departure of then chief executive Malcolm Bundey after the financial performance deteriorated.

Pact shares were sitting at $5.30 in mid-August 2018 and have now more than halved. Profit margins in 2018-19 declined to 8.1 per cent from 9.8 per cent. The value of Mr Geminder's stake has now dropped by more than $400 million in the past year alone.

Advertisement

Goldman Sachs said the modest outlook for the company was subdued, and it appeared the group had moved past the absolute worst point.

The bottom-line loss of $290 million compared with a net profit of $74 million a year ago. Revenues were up 10 per cent to $1.83 billion, as acquisitions such as the TIC garment hangers business which came on to the books in October 31 made a contribution.

Long-term priority

Mr Dayal said the review would be extensive but it was being done with a long-term view of making sure there was limited investment in products which weren't a long-term priority and capable of delivering decent returns.

"I have introduced a sort of customer overlay to the network redesign program,'' he said.

Pact has already closed two packaging plants in the June half at Bankstown in Sydney, and one in Melbourne, under an overhaul started by Mr Geminder.

Mr Dayal said once some renewed momentum happened in the business and customers became more confident, an acceleration would occur. "It's not going to take years.''

Pact began a large contract with grocery retailer Aldi on August 1 for re-usable crates for fresh produce, and Mr Dayal said that was an important win.

Advertisement

Pact also announced on Wednesday that Peter Margin, the executive chairman of Asahi's Australian beverages operations, would step down from the board. Asahi made a $16 billion buyout for beer business CUB last month.

Mr Geminder is the brother-in-law of Australia's richest person, Anthony Pratt, and a regular in the Financial Review Rich List.

Pact was formed in 2002 after Mr Geminder engineered the management buyout of several underperforming assets from Visy Industries. Pact listed on the ASX in late 2013 at an issue price of $3.80.
description: The value of Rich Lister Raphael Geminder's stake has shrunk by $400m in 12 months but the new CEO vows he can reinvent the packaging group.
